data.title: What is a ccTLD?
data.meta_description: Country Code Top Level Domains (ccTLD) are suffixes used to define domains for a specific country or area. Almost every country has its own ccTLD. For example, ".au" is the ccTLD for Australia.
data.text:
More About ccTLDs

The domain registration process for ccTLDs may vary depending on each countryâ€™s requirements. In some cases, you can only register ccTLDs with specific regional registrars.

Examples of Popular ccTLDs include:

.US (United States)

.CO (Colombia)

.CN (China)

.UK (United Kingdom)

.CA (Canada)

.DE (Germany)

.BR (Brazil)

.MX (Mexico)

Some countries will limit ccTLD access to government organizations or local-purpose entities. Local domain authorities can also dictate registration periods, as well as how renewals and transfers work.

ccTLDs and Rankings
